leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 30] s 30 Conferral of jurisdiction (cf LCA 1982, section 65)

p.text: Subject to this Part, the Court sitting in its General Division has jurisdiction to hear and determine:

proceedings on any money claim, so long as the amount claimed, whether on a balance of account or after an admitted set-off or otherwise, does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the Court when sitting in that Division, and

proceedings to recover detained goods, or to recover the assessed value of detained goods, so long as the value of the goods, together with the amount of any consequential damages claimed for their detention, does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the Court when sitting in that Division, and
proceedings that, pursuant to any other Act, are required to be dealt with by the Court sitting in that Division.
Subject to this Part, the Court sitting in its Small Claims Division has jurisdiction to hear and determine:

proceedings on any money claim, so long as the amount claimed, whether on a balance of account or after an admitted set-off or otherwise, does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the Court when sitting in that Division, and

proceedings to recover detained goods, or to recover the assessed value of detained goods, so long as the value of the goods, together with the amount of any consequential damages claimed for their detention, does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the Court when sitting in that Division.
Nothing in subsection (2) prevents proceedings under that subsection from being heard and determined by the Court sitting in its General Division.
In determining an amount for the purposes of subsection (1) or (2) , any interest up to judgment under section 100 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 is to be disregarded.
If:
the jurisdictional limit of a Division is increased, and
proceedings in which an amount of money is claimed are pending in the Court when that increase takes effect,
the Court may, on the application of a plaintiff, make an order altering the amount specified in the claim to an amount not exceeding the new jurisdictional limit.
In this section, admitted set-off, in relation to proceedings, means set-off admitted by the plaintiff in the originating process in the proceedings.
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 30.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 29.
See the notes to LCA 2007 s 29 , above.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 30.10] LCA 2007 s 30(1),(2) ″proceedings to recover detained goods″

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 30.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 67, s 90.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 33(1)(d).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 16.5.

heading.title: LCA 2007 s 30(1),(2) "proceedings to recover detained goods"

p.text: See also CPA s 90 "Judgment for detention of goods"; CPA s 67 "No jurisdiction in proceedings for detention of goods where (a) goods the subject of a hire-purchase agreement"; or (b) "where the goods are detained by their owner or by some other person acting on the owner's behalf"; LCA 2007 s 33(1)(d) (no jurisdiction in proceedings for detention where goods the subject of a hire-purchase agreement etc); UCPR r 16.5 : "default judgment on claim for detention of goods".
See Ex parte Kelly (1903) 20 WN (NSW) 186; Evans v Wedderburn (1894) 15 LR (NSW) 482; Article 8 ALJ 182.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 30.25] LCA 2007 s 30(1)(c) ″pursuant to any other Act″

heading.title: LCA 2007 s 30(1)(c) "pursuant to any other Act"

p.text: See the other instances of jurisdiction specified in [LCA07 Pt 3.0] above.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 30.30] Interaction with Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 30.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 subs (1).
(CTH) Family Law Act 1975 s 119, s 39, s 4(1), s 75.
(NSW) Married Persons (Equality of Status) Act 1996 ss 5, 6.

Under subs (1) , the Local Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine "proceeding on any money claim", that is "a claim for recovery of any debt, demand or damage (whether liquidated or unliquidated)". The Family Court (or in appropriate circumstances, a court of summary jurisdiction) has jurisdiction in respect of matrimonial causes: Family Law Act 1975 s 39 . “Matrimonial cause” means, inter alia, "(ca) proceedings between the parties to a marriage with respect to the property of the parties to the marriage or either of them, being proceedings … (i) arising out of the marital relationship … ": Family Law Act 1975 s 4(1) . However, "every party to a marriage may bring proceedings in contract or in tort against the other party": s 119 of the Family Law Act; cf Married Persons (Equality of Status) Act 1996 (NSW) ss 5 , 6 . In order for property disputes between husband and wife to be arbitrated under the Family Law Act, they must have some connection with the matrimonial relationship: Russell v Russell (1976) 134 CLR 495; 9 ALR 103; 1 Fam LR 11,133; BC7600041 . In Slattery v Slattery (1976) 2 Fam LR 11,251; 12 ALR 266; 27 FLR 115; (1976) FLC ¶90–110 , the Full Court of the Family Court held that the Family Court did not have jurisdiction to order the repayment of money lent by a wife to a husband during the course of a marriage, since the payment of a loan was not:
a matter of alteration of property interests since it did not deal with any particular item of property of a party to the marriage.

See also Bate v Priestley (1989) 13 Fam LR 376; 97 FLR 310; (1990) FLC ¶92-102; BC8901632 where the majority of the New South Wales Court of Appeal held that proceedings to enforce a deed of acknowledgment of debt by the wife against her former husband did not arise out of the parties' former marital relationship, but out of the deed.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 30.35] Interaction with Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 (commenced 25 February 2002)

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 30.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 [285,100], s 22(3), s 22(7), s 23.

heading.title: Interaction with Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 (commenced 25 February 2002)

p.text: If, at the time an application was made to the Tribunal, no issue arising under the application was the subject of a dispute in proceedings pending before a court, a court has no jurisdiction to hear or determine such an issue: Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 22(3) .

If, at the time an application is made to the Tribunal, an issue arising under the application was the subject of a dispute in proceedings pending before a court, the Tribunal, on becoming aware of those proceedings, ceases to have jurisdiction to hear or determine the issue: Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 22(7) .
Proceedings may be transferred to from Tribunal to court and from court to Tribunal in the circumstances set out in Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 23 .
The relevant provisions of the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 may be found at [285,100] behind guide card “Other Legislation”.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 31] s 31 Jurisdictional limits may be exceeded for certain money claims (cf LCA 1982, section 66)

leg:heading.title: Jurisdictional limits may be exceeded for certain money claims (cf LCA 1982, section 66 )

p.text: When sitting in its General Division, the Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine proceedings on a money claim for an amount not exceeding 20 per cent more than the jurisdictional limit of the Court when sitting in its General Division:
if a memorandum of consent has been filed in relation to the proceedings, or
if no objection to the Court’s jurisdiction has been raised by any of the parties prior to one month before the trial of the proceedings commences.
A memorandum of consent referred to in subsection (1)(a) does not have effect unless:
it is signed by each party to the proceedings, or by the party’s Australian legal practitioner, and

it states that each of those parties consents to the proceedings being heard and determined by the Court and is aware that, unless the memorandum is filed, the Court will not have jurisdiction to hear or determine the proceedings.
This section applies despite section 30(1)(a) .
Nothing in this section limits the operation of section 140 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005.
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 31.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 140, s 140(4).
CPA s 140 , in particular s 140(4) , relates to the transfer of proceedings from a lower court (the Local Court) to a higher court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 32] s 32 Jurisdiction in proceedings for review of contracts (cf LCA 1982, section 68)

leg:heading.title: Jurisdiction in proceedings for review of contracts (cf LCA 1982, section 68 )

p.text: The Court has the same jurisdiction as the Supreme Court, and may exercise all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court, to refuse to enforce any or all of the provisions of a contract under section 7(1)(a) of the Contracts Review Act 1980.

This section applies only if application for the exercise of the jurisdiction is made in proceedings concerning the contract that have previously been commenced in the Court but have not been determined.
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 32.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 32, s 32(2).
(NSW) Contracts Review Act 1980 [295,000], s 7(1)(a).

LCA 2007 s 32 confers on the Local Court, with limitations, a jurisdiction similar to that presently conferred on the Supreme and District Courts by the Contracts Review Act 1980 , and which enables those courts to refuse to enforce a contract. The Local Court is only empowered to grant relief under Contracts Review Act 1980 s 7(1)(a) , and may only exercise the jurisdiction thus conferred if application for the exercise of the jurisdiction is made in proceedings concerning the contract that have previously been commenced in the court but have not been determined: LCA 2007 s 32(2) . (The previous section dealing with this issue read “only if application for the exercise of the jurisdiction is made in proceedings concerning the contract that are in the course of being heard by the Court: LCA 1982 s 68(2) ). That is, the court has no power to exercise jurisdiction independently of proceedings previously commenced in the Court which remain undetermined). Before the Local Court originally achieved this power by an amendment to the now repealed Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 which became effective in 1993, proceedings in which a defendant raised a defence under the Contracts Review Act frequently had to be transferred to the District Court, since at that time the Local Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the defence. In some instances the defence was validly raised. In others, it was a tactical and time-wasting ploy. LCA 1982 s 68(3) (repealed) also contained a provision providing that the section “does not authorise a Court to exercise the jurisdiction conferred by any other provision of the Contracts Review Act 1980: LCA 1982 s 68(3) . The omission may be thought to have occurred because the section only stated a principle which was self-evident. The Contracts Review Act 1980 is set out at [295,000] .
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 32.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Contracts Review Act 1980 [295,075]–[295,075-20].

“Purpose of the Act”, “Three stage process in determining applications for relief”, “Limited nature of discretionary relief”” and “Unjust contracts generally”: see commentary at [295,075]–[295,075-20] inclusive.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 33] s 33 Certain jurisdiction excluded (cf LCA 1982, section 67)

p.text: The Court does not have jurisdiction under this Part to hear or determine any of the following kinds of proceedings:
proceedings in which the validity or effect of any devise, bequest or limitation under any will or settlement, or under any document in the nature of a settlement, is disputed,
proceedings for passing-off, wrongful arrest, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution or defamation,
proceedings for infringement of letters patent or copyright,
proceedings for detention of goods:
where the goods are the subject of a hire-purchase agreement, or
where the goods are detained by their owner or by some other person acting on the owner’s behalf,
proceedings in which the title to land is in question (other than proceedings on a claim in respect of which the question of the title to land is merely incidental).

The judgment of the Court in proceedings on a claim in respect of which the question of the title to land is merely incidental, as referred to in subsection (1)(e) , is not admissible as evidence of the title to the land in any other legal proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 33.5] LCA 2007 s 33(1)(e) — Actions in which the title to land is in question

heading.title: LCA 2007 s 33(1)(e) — Actions in which the title to land is in question

p.text: The question of title must be bona fide in dispute. A mere allegation cannot oust the court's jurisdiction: Ex parte Charlton (1869) 8 SCR (NSW) 158 . Thus, where the defendant had acquiesced in the plaintiff's title over a period of four years, but at the trial of an action for damages for trespass to the land in question, endeavoured to make him prove it, thereby seeking to raise the question of title in order to oust the court's jurisdiction, the District Court had jurisdiction: Ex parte McEvoy (1868) 8 SCR (NSW) 16; O'Brien v Wilson (1894) 15 LR(NSW) 291; 11 WN (NSW) 53. Further, to oust the jurisdiction of the court on the basis that the title to land is in question the claim set up must be “a bona fide one and the right one that can exist in point of law”, and a spurious claim based upon an alleged immemorial custom is insufficient: Lloyd v Jones (1848) 6 CB 81; 136 ER 1182 . The court cannot give itself jurisdiction by determining that the question of title to land is not bona fide in dispute against the weight of evidence: Ex parte Gane (1887) 3 WN (NSW) 137.

Where the action was one in which the existence of a right of way acquired by the public by use is in question, although the plaintiff did not dispute that the defendant had a legal estate and did not claim a freehold or leasehold interest in the land, he set up a claim which tended to cut down the defendant's interest in or right over the land and hence the court was without jurisdiction: Ex parte M'Gregor (1881) 2 LR (NSW) 45. Where a defendant claimed that land where seizure of sheep had taken place was his by virtue of a Crown lease and the plaintiff maintained that the land was part of land leased to him by the Crown, the fact being that the dispute was as to boundaries, it was held that jurisdiction ceased on the fact appearing that the title to land was in question: Ex parte Farelly (1868) 7 SCR (NSW) 227. In an action for the wrongful cutting down and removal of a fence on a forfeited selection which was the subject of reselection, it was held that the question concerned the property in the fence and that the District Court judge's decision that he had no jurisdiction was wrong: Thompson v Rix (1886) 2 WN (NSW) 87. In actions for rates brought by a borough or municipality, a dispute as to what is the boundary of a municipality is not such a question of title as will oust the jurisdiction of the court.

“If the dispute had been between two ratepayers it might have involved such a question of title as would have ousted the jurisdiction; but it appears, so far as we can see to have been merely whether the defendant should pay rates to one municipality or to the other. In any action to recover rates, the municipality suing must show that the property rated is within the municipal boundary, and if there is any question as to what is the correct boundary, the judge must decide the point”: Borough of Camperdown v Prendergast (1888) 5 WN (NSW) 30 at 30. However, the question does arise if the defendant denies that he is the owner of the land in question: Borough of Granville v Armstrong (1897) 18 LR (NSW) 426; 14 WN (NSW) 63. A bona fide dispute as to whether a freehold is a clear fee simple or is subject to a lease is a question directly involving the title to land and therefore the court has no jurisdiction to determine the question: Smith v Pattison (1934) 51 WN (NSW) 137 . An action for the delivery up of certificate of title is not one in which the title to land is in question, the issue being who was entitled to possession of the actual certificate of title as between plaintiff and defendant: Laycock v Putty Community Assn Inc [2006] NSWSC 900; BC200607189 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 34] s 34 Jurisdiction when cause of action or defendant outside the State (cf LCA 1982, section 69)

leg:heading.title: Jurisdiction when cause of action or defendant outside the State (cf LCA 1982, section 69 )

p.text: The Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine proceedings with respect to a cause of action:
even if part of the cause of action arose outside New South Wales, so long as a material part of the cause of action arose within New South Wales, and
even if the whole cause of action arose outside New South Wales, so long as the defendant was resident in New South Wales at the time of service of the document that commenced the proceedings, and
even if the defendant is not within New South Wales, so long as:
the whole or a material part of the cause of action arose within New South Wales, and

the defendant was within a State or a part of the Commonwealth (within the meaning of the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 of the Commonwealth) at the time of service of the document that commenced the proceedings.
Subsection (1)(c) applies whether or not the defendant has ever been resident or carried on business in New South Wales.
In this section, defendant includes, if there are 2 or more defendants, any one of those defendants.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 34.5] The common law position — actions in personam

heading.title: The common law position — actions in personam

p.text: At common law, the court's jurisdiction in an action in personam depended not on the subject matter of the suit, but upon the amenability of the defendant to the writ expressing the sovereign's command, and the writ did not run beyond the geographical limits of the state. An action in personam (that is, an action between parties) is one that is brought in order to settle the rights of the parties as between themselves, and is to be distinguished from an action in rem which is one brought in order to vindicate a jus in rem, that is a right such as ownership available against all persons. The common law principle was that where the writ could not be legally served upon the defendant, the court had no jurisdiction over him, but in an action in personam whenever the defendant could be legally served with the writ, or service being effected, the court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit against him. As to the above principles, see Laurie v Carroll (1958) 98 CLR 310; 32 ALJR 7 ; Cotter v Workman (1972) 20 FLR 318 ; Coppin v Tobler Bros Canberra Marine Centre Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 183 .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 34.10] The legislative pre-history to LCA 2007 s 34

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 34.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 subs (1).
(NSW) Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 17.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 s 15(1), [415,000].
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 67.

heading.title: The legislative pre-history to LCA 2007 s 34

p.text: Prior to 1 January 1990, the Local Court was without jurisdiction in each of the circumstances mentioned in subs (1) . Prior to an amendment which became effective on that date, the relevant section in the Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 ( s 17 ) invested the court with jurisdiction "notwithstanding that the defendant or one of two or more defendants is not within NSW". This terminology overcame to some extent the difficulties of the common law rule enunciated in Cotter v Workman (1972) 20 FLR 318 and Laurie v Carroll (1958) 98 CLR 310; 32 ALJR 7 . However, the Local Court, being an inferior court, was still without jurisdiction unless the plaintiff could prove that every fact material to be proved to entitle the plaintiff to succeed had occurred within the jurisdiction: Cooke v Gill (1873) LR 8 CP 107 applied in R v O'Neill; Ex parte Moran (1985) 58 ACTR 26 ; see also Trower & Sons Ltd v Ripstein [1944] AC 254 . The present section (which reflects LC(CC) Act 1970 s 17 as it became following the 1990 amendments and LCA 1982 s 69 (repealed)), overcomes these problems.

As regards service, note that under Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) s 15(1) (effective 10 April 1993), initiating process may now be served anywhere in Australia. In other words, it does not matter that the defendant is not amenable to jurisdiction in the common law sense because he or she is outside the territorial borders of the State, provided the defendant is within Australia. Under s 20(3), a court may stay the proceedings “if it is satisfied that a court of another state that has jurisdiction to determine all the matters in issue between the parties is the appropriate court to determine those matters.” As to the principles which a court may take into account in deciding whether to grant a stay under the section, see the notes to CPA s 67 on the subject of inconvenient local forum at [s 67.50] and [s 67.55] . The Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) may be found at [415,000] behind the guide card "Other Legislation".
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 34.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 34.

This phrase has been judicially considered in the context of a variety of statutory enactments conferring jurisdiction in similar terms to s 34 . In Read v Brown (1888) 22 QBD 128 it was defined as meaning “every fact which it would be necessary for the plaintiff to prove, if traversed, in order to support his right to the judgment of the court. It does not comprise every piece of evidence which is necessary to prove each fact, but every fact which is necessary to be proved": at 131, following Cooke v Gill (1873) LR 8 CP 107. In Williams v Milotin (1957) 97 CLR 465 at 474; [1957] ALR 1145; BC5700520 (per Dixon CJ, McTiernan, Williams, Webb and Kitto JJ) it was defined as "the essential ingredients in the title to the right which it is proposed to enforce". In Jackson v Spittall (1870) LR 5 CP 542 at 552 it was held that the expression “cause of action” did not mean “the cause of action”, that is every fact material to be proved to entitle the plaintiff to succeed, but that it was used in what may be described as a more or less popular sense as indicating the particular act or omission occasioning the injustice complained of, and so giving rise to the plaintiff's claim.

The Jackson v Spittall definition has been preferred in a number of recent cases concerning the jurisdiction of particular courts where those courts' claims to jurisdiction were in contest. For example, in the Distillers Co (Bio-Chemicals) Ltd v Thompson [1971] AC 458; [1971] 1 NSWLR 83; [1971] 1 A ll ER 694 ; (one of the thalidomide cases) company A had manufactured a drug outside the jurisdiction, it being sold within the jurisdiction by company B in a package containing a leaflet prepared by company A which contained no warning of the drug's possible side effects. It was held (applying Jackson v Spittall (1870) LR 5 CP 542), that the plaintiff was entitled to complain of company A's failure to give her warning that the goods sold would be dangerous if taken by an expectant mother in the first three months of pregnancy as being negligence by the defendant in NSW causing injury to the plaintiff there, and thus the cause of action arose within the jurisdiction of the court in which the action was brought. In Jacobs v Australian Abrasives Pty Ltd [1971] Tas SR 92 , an abrasive wheel made by the defendant in NSW was brought by the plaintiff into Tasmania. The wheel broke and injured the plaintiff. It was held that the defendant as manufacturer had a duty of care to the plaintiff as ultimate consumer and that duty was breached when the wheel came into his hands without an adequate warning of its danger and how to avoid it, so that the defendant had committed a tort within the jurisdiction. In My v Toyota Motor Co Ltd [1977] 2 NZLR 113 the delivery in New Zealand by an overseas manufacturer of an allegedly defective machine made by it abroad was an "act for which damages are claimed … done in New Zealand” delivery being an essential part of the cause of action coupled with the allegedly negligent manufacture and resultant damage. In other words it is sufficient that the particular act or omission directly occasioning the relevant injury or damage takes place within the jurisdiction: Jackson v Spittall, above. However, in Chidzey v Breckler [1920] VLR 558; (1920) 27 ALR 14 where the contract was made in Perth, and the breach thereof took place in Perth, it was held that there was no cause of action arising within Victoria, even though delivery was to be made from Melbourne.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 34.20] LCA 2007 s 34(1)(b) — “Even if the whole cause of action arose outside NSW”

heading.title: LCA 2007 s 34(1)(b) — “Even if the whole cause of action arose outside NSW”

p.text: This means outside NSW, and includes within other states of Australia or other countries, such as New Zealand. Consequently, the court has jurisdiction where the defendant was resident within NSW at the time of service and was before the court, notwithstanding that the contract upon which the action was brought was made in New Zealand and breached there: Marac Financial Services Ltd v Walsh (Waverley Local Court, PC 8028/91, Bailey M, 9 September 1992, unreported).

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 34.25] LCA 2007 s 34(1)(c) — “The whole or a material part of the cause of action arose within NSW”

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 34.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 47(1)(c).
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 34(1)(c).

heading.title: LCA 2007 s 34(1)(c) — “The whole or a material part of the cause of action arose within NSW”

p.text: In Thomas v Penna (1985) 2 NSWLR 171 , Nash DCJ held that the virtually identical phrase used in District Court Act 1973 s 47(1)(c) (as it then stood) meant any one or more of the essential elements of the claim entitling the plaintiff to recover a verdict, but not relating solely to the quantum of that verdict. Nash DCJ was adjudicating upon a cause of action in tort complete in all respects in Queensland, including damage, there being only consequential suffering in NSW, which went solely to quantum as distinct from being an essential element of the plaintiff's claim. Quaere whether had damage been suffered in NSW, as distinct from consequential damage going only to quantum, this would have constituted “a material part of the cause of action for the purposes of s 34(1)(c) .” Nash DCJ thought so, and thought that had the Distillers case (Distillers Co (Bio-Chemicals) Ltd v Thompson [1971] AC 458; [1971] 1 NSWLR 83; [1971] 1 All ER 694 ) been decided on the factual basis that the only damage was suffered in NSW, this would have constituted a material part of the cause of action. The reasoning in Thomas v Penna, above was affirmed by the NSW Court of Appeal in Falls Creek Ski Lifts Pty Ltd v Yee (1995) 37 NSWLR 344; BC9505458 . This is an entirely distinct issue from the question as to whether a tort may be said to have been committed within the jurisdiction where all the essential elements occur outside the jurisdiction save damage which occurs within. Thus in George Monro Ltd v American Cyanamid & Chemical Corp [1944] 1 KB 432; [1944] 1 All ER 386 it was held that the words "tort committed within the jurisdiction" must be limited to a wrongful act committed within the jurisdiction, and do not extend to a case where the wrongful act was committed outside, but the damage resulting from the act occurred within the jurisdiction. This view is consistent with that expressed in Hall v Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority [1980] 2 NSWLR 26; (1980) 31 ALR 557 , a case concerning an electrically caused fire which commenced in the ACT and spread into NSW causing damage, where it was held that the suffering of damage within the jurisdiction alone would not attract the operation of Service and Execution of Process Act 1901 (Cth) s 11(1)(d) ; and with that in Buttigeig v Universal Terminal and Stevedoring Corp [1972] VR 626 , where the plaintiff was injured as a result of falling through a sheet of flooring in the hold of a ship in Melbourne. It was held that the action against the third defendant (the stevedoring company responsible for storage of the cargo on the ship in New York) was not founded on a tort committed within the jurisdiction since no act of the defendant giving the plaintiff a cause of complaint occurred in Victoria. Further, in the Distillers' case , above, the Privy Council held that it was not correct to say, in an action of tort, that because there is no complete tort until the damage has occurred, therefore the cause of action arises where the damage happens to occur, nor that the cause of action arises where the last ingredient, that is the event which completes the cause of action, occurs. However, according to the dicta of Nash DCJ, in each of the above cases it may be said that a material part of the cause of action arose within the jurisdiction on the basis that the tort of negligence is not complete until actual loss or damage occurs, the cause of action being inchoate at the stage when the breach of duty takes place. “Material” is defined in the Macquarie Dictionary as, inter alia, “any constituent element of a thing.”

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 34.30] Determining where a breach of contract has occurred

heading.title: Determining where a breach of contract has occurred

p.text: This depends upon the nature of the conduct which is alleged to constitute the breach. Thus, where the breach relied upon is repudiation by means of letter, telex, telephone conversation or cable, the breach will generally be held to have occurred at the place from which the message was sent: Stanley Kerr Holdings Pty Ltd v Gibor Textile Enterprises Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 372 : repudiation of contract by means of telex from Israel; held that no breach had occurred in NSW; the breach had occurred in Israel; Safran v Chani (1970) 72 SR (NSW) 146; 91 WN (NSW) 186 : breach of promise of marriage, by means of letter forwarded from Melbourne; held that the breach of contract, if there were a contract, took place where the letters were posted and the words of repudiation were spoken, that is, Melbourne; Martin v Stout [1925] AC 359 : contracts repudiated by a cable despatched from England; held that the cable repudiating the contracts having been despatched in England, the breach took place there. The rationale behind the principle was explained by Blackburn J in Cherry v Thompson (1872) LR 7 QB 573 at 579 thus:

In this case, the receipt of the letter by the plaintiff in England furnished him with evidence that the defendant had in Germany renounced the contract. Had his letter followed him to Ireland, he would have received the evidence in Ireland. But the act which he had the option to treat as a breach took place in Germany.

The above cases may be described as cases of anticipatory breach by repudiation. Repudiation in such circumstances does not of itself discharge the contract. It only gives the other party the option of either treating the contract as at an end, or of waiting until the stipulated time has arrived or the contingency upon which the performance of the contract was dependent has happened: Martin v Stout [1925] AC 359 at 364 . But see Crawford Fitting Co v Sydney Valve & Fitting Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Priestley, McHugh, Clarke JJ, 23 June 1986, unreported, BC8600897) where the breach relied upon was the improper giving of notice, and the breach was held to have occurred at the place where the notice was received.

Where the breach alleged is non-payment of money due under a contract, then the breach will arise at the place where the parties have expressly or impliedly agreed that payment shall be made: Haldane v Johnson (1853) 8 Exch 689; 155 ER 1529 ; Shallay Holdings Pty Ltd v Griffith Co-op Society Ltd [1983] 1 VR 760; (1982) 48 ALR 304 . In the absence of an express provision in a contract of guarantee, the place for payment is the place where in all the circumstances the parties should be taken to have impliedly intended: Earthworks and Quarries Ltd v FT Eastment & Sons Pty Ltd [1966] VR 24 at 26; (1965) 8 FLR 32 . In BP Australia Ltd v Wales [1982] Qd R 386 , it was held that the parties had impliedly intended that the place at which the plaintiffs conducted the account would move from place to place; that it was open to the plaintiff to have advised the defendant that it had fixed a place in Queensland but had not done so, and that therefore no breach had occurred in Queensland.
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 34.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 11, r 11.1.

The Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) imposes a gloss upon the rule in Cotter v Workman (1972) 20 FLR 318 , in that provided the preconditions set out in the Act are satisfied, the court may exercise jurisdiction over a person, notwithstanding that he or she is outside the court's territorial jurisdiction and is served outside the jurisdiction, though within Australia. Section 69 has nothing to say about modes of service where the defendant is outside the jurisdiction, and in this regard, where the defendant is outside the state, the Local Court's jurisdiction will only be attracted where the provisions of the Service and Execution of Process Act have been observed. Thus:

" … the question … is whether the court has power in the circumstances of this case to exercise jurisdiction over a person or corporation not personally served within it. If a party has been personally served within the jurisdiction, even though merely temporarily there, the jurisdiction of the court is generally established, but a court will not generally be entitled to assume jurisdiction over a person who is outside the jurisdiction and has not been formally served within it and who does not submit to the jurisdiction. If that power is to be exercised it must be given to the court by legislation [Ed: in this instance by the Service and Execution of Process Act in the case of persons or corporations resident in other states or territories of Australia] … If he is found within the jurisdiction of the court and served there, he will generally be bound by the process. Equally he may be bound if he submits to the jurisdiction, but otherwise the court has no power unless it is expressly conferred on it. It is a question, not of practice but of jurisdiction, whether the court has the power to serve a summons on a party resident abroad, so that the party may be brought within the jurisdiction of what is, to him a foreign court.The exercise of the power involves the exercise of extra-territorial jurisdiction": Trower & Sons Ltd v Ripstein [1944] AC 254 at 261–2 .

In Commonwealth Bank of Australia v White [1999] 2 VR 681; [1999] VSC 262; BC9904419 , the court was required to consider the issue of service upon a foreign corporation never registered in Australia as a foreign company. Dealing with the matter on common law principles, the court considered that the company had a sufficient presence in Australia to enable it to be served through its agent in Sydney.

The provisions of the UCPR Pt 11 , relating to service of documents outside Australia relate only to proceedings in the Supreme Court: UCPR r 11.1 . In the normal course, Local Court process cannot be served outside Australia. However, if process comes to the notice of a defendant outside Australia, and a defence is filed not contesting the issue of jurisdiction, the defendant will generally be taken to have consented to the court's jurisdiction.
